title: The Debt That Binds
tagline: In the shadow of the Acropolis, a young enforcer learns that in Athens, every man is either a creditor or a slave.
themes: Predatory Economics in a Democratic Polis

story: Write a chapter from the perspective of the fish-sauce merchant's daughter, exploring the illness and the terror of her father's debt.
Draft a monologue by Philon the Lender explaining his economic philosophy to a skeptical Athenian aristocrat.
Create a scene where Brasidas reflects on his own past and why he enforces the system that enslaved him.
Write a 'deleted scene' showing a conversation between Xanthias and the slave girl at the well, one year after the novel's events.
technical: Build an interactive 'Debt Web' visualization showing how characters in the novel are financially and socially entangled.
Design a text-based game where the player, as Xanthias, must make moral choices in debt collection, with consequences for loyalty, wealth, and freedom.

council: Aristotle (on political economy and the nature of slavery)
Euripides (on the psychology of the oppressed and social critique)
George Orwell (on the mechanics of power and the enforcer's dilemma)
Upton Sinclair (on exposing the brutal systems underpinning a society)
